title: Leaving the EU dealership with dignity
text:
ANALYSIS/OPINION:

Imagine that for many years you have bought your cars from the same showroom, but then your kids get on your case because they’ve found better deals on the Internet and they get you to cancel your existing plan. Trouble is the car dealers get really mad.

Diplomatically you say to them, “Look, you know I love coming to you guys. You are close by and I really don’t want to have to travel all over to find new deals, but I’ve got to keep the family happy, too. Can you help me out?”

They say, “OK, but if you wanna break your current plan and still keep your discounts, it’s gonna cost something — I mean, we don’t wanna be giving ideas to our other customers, right?”

So you say, “OK, OK, I’m sorry, it’s just kids these days. How much is it going to cost?”

They look you straight in the eyes and say, “$48 billion.”

You say, “Wow, and what do I get for that?”

They say, “We’ll let you know that once you’ve signed on the line.”

So you say, “Great! I’ll go tell the kids.”

Absurd? Well that, roughly, is how Theresa May’s Brexit negotiations with the EU went. Nigel Farage dubbed her withdrawal agreement a “surrender document.”

Japan recently signed a huge free trade agreement with the EU, but free was not available for Britain. The U.K. needed to be made an example of.

The EU’s Brexit bruiser, Guy Verhofstadt, has threatened, “If the U.K. doesn’t pay what is due, the EU will not negotiate a trade deal.” He added, “After ‘no deal,’ this will be a first condition of any talks.”

The U.K. is already estimated to have paid the EU/EEC half a trillion pounds sterling since it joined in 1973, but that has bought precious little good will from its European neighbors.

Proponents of paying for a deal point to the benefits. The U.K.’s Department for International Trade has said the EU-Japan trade deal alone would increase U.K. GDP by up to $3.7 billion “in the longer term.”

That means Britain pays $48 billion to get $3.7 billion back — go figure that one.

Now it is Mr. Johnson’s turn to deal with the EU, and President Trump feels he is doing very well. At the G7 summit in France, he told reporters, “He needs no advice. He’s the right man for the job.”

But Nigel Farage is not convinced, “I think Boris Johnson is going all out for an amended withdrawal agreement.” Mr. Farage has made it clear his Brexit Party will only support him if he is willing to leave the EU without a deal.

Mr. Farage’s worry is that the only change Mr. Johnson wants to make to Mrs. May’s deal is to drop the “Irish Backstop.”

The “Backstop” was agreed by Mrs. May to try to solve the problem of the EU needing custom checks at the end of its trading zone. After Brexit this would lie between Northern and Southern Ireland and it could have led to a hard border being reinstated between them.

Many Conservatives argued that new technology for tracking lorries and goods makes border checks unnecessary, but Mrs. May buckled under the EU threats to build one.

She was terrified of “the troubles” flaring up again. Added to that Nancy Pelosi threatened to block any U.S. trade deals with Britain if Brexit endangered the “Good Friday Agreement” that has brought peace to Northern Ireland.

The House speaker should have known that the EU was threatening the hard border, not Britain, but why let facts get in the way of spoiling a Trump trade deal?

Mrs. May’s compromise was to have checks on goods coming in by sea to the British mainland, but this would have separated Northern Ireland from the rest of the U.K. and effectively kept it in the EU, possibly leading to a furious backlash from Unionists.

Furthermore, had Parliament agreed to Mrs. May’s “vassal state” withdrawal agreement then Britain could have been tied to the EU’s custom’s union and may not have been able to sign a trade deal with America — or anyone else.

Boris Johnson wants to get rid of the “Irish Backstop” and to reduce their $48 billion demand. Yet, finding such a deal before the Oct. 31 leave date seems increasingly unlikely, so “Remainers” are demanding the date is delayed yet again.

Parliament returned this week with old scores to settle. The prime minister’s Conservative Party — which includes his brother, Parliament member Jo Johnson — faced the combined onslaught of angry “Remainer” MPs who want him removed.

If the “Remain” gang succeeds, it could lead to “Vote-fight at the O.K. Parliament” for the Johnson brothers in an electoral showdown over Brexit. Will Nigel Farage become an unlikely Doc Holliday?

Maybe, but first they would have to tell the EU dealership, “no-deal.”

• Andrew Davies is a U.K.-based video producer and scriptwriter.
